column2: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (U.P.)-- The 9,000 books in the lifetime collection of the late President Woodrow Wilson have been given to the Library of Congress by Mrs. Wilson, it was announced tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 10 (AP)--Russia formally has requested a revision of the Montreux Convention, an international pact governing both war and peacetime traffic through the vital Dardanelles, an unofficial but reliable source said tonight.

THE life of Tom Horn ran in the familiar frontier pattern and had no variety save that of excess. Raised in border Missouri and subjected to the alternate harshness and indifference of an old-fashioned family, he felt the pull of the Farther West and soon escaped to it, a rather ignorant young man, to whom adventure was synonymous with freedom from discipline.

CHAUTAUQUA N.Y., Aug. 10 --The same forces of reaction who fought so hard against price control are today at work "undermining Wilson Wyatt's housing program," Senator James M. Mead charged today in his first major address since Congress adjourned.
AMONG recent books on the international situation, this is one of the most stimulating, both for the novelty of its approach and the lucidity of its analysis.

A succession of severe earthquakes shook Puerto Rico, Santo Domingo and Haiti last week-the most severe since 1918. The loss of life was not great, but the damage to property was heavy. So strong were the shocks that they were recorded at St. Louis, 2,000 miles away.

THIS book is not Mr. Longstreet's "first offense in writ ing family history," as he puts it. Because so many people wanted more in the vein of "Nine Lives With Grandfather," he has turned out a bubbling batch of reminiscences about Mama and her sister, the two most beautiful women in their town--or in New York, when they were in it.

A warning that food shortages in Europe would be more acute this coming winter than last year was made yesterday by three officials of the Lutheran Church, just returned to the United States after a tour of several countries on the Continent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--A United States mission will sail from New York Tuesday on the steamship Argentina to participate in Allied efforts to gain control of German assets in Spain and Portugal for Allied reparations accounts.

PEIPING, Aug. 10 (U.E)--United States Marine Corps Headquarters announced today that a second clash between Marines and Chinese Communists had taken place when a coal train was attacked and derailed sixty miles northeast of Tientsin last night.

THOSE wonderfully lucid and persuasive editorials on world government that have been appearing unsigned in the "Notes and Comments" section of The New Yorker were written by E.B. White. This, one of the most poorly kept secrets in years, is officially revealed by Houghton Mifflin, who announce with justified jubilance that they will be published late this year in a book to be called "The Wild Flag."

TOKYO, Aug. 10--A moderately comprehensive outline of the policies Soviet Russia would like to see followed in Japan if it had the power to dictate them, as well as some idea of the tactics the large, well-heeled Russian liaison mission here has already undertaken, has now begun to emerge in the occupation picture.

Yesterday, after a fortnight of speechmaking and angry debate, the Conference of Paris began the work for which it was originally convened. It officially started consideration of peace treaties for Italy, Rumania, Hungary, ...

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Aug. 10--The origins of the merger of the American and British zones of occupation in Germany stem from economic necessity. But the merger is assuming political importance because, with the best of will, economic and political fields cannot be wholly separated and also because the Russians choose to attach such importance to it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)-- Members of the House Military Affairs Committee took off today for a six weeks' trip to Alaska, the Pacific and the Far East.
PARIS, Aug. 10--Albania will seek Italian reparations mostly in the form of labor and material to rebuild her fascist-devastated regions, an authoritative source said today.

AN innocent man has been condemned to death, and Terry Clane sets out to prove that Edward Harold did not commit the murder for which he is to die unless new evidence can be found to exonerate him. Clane has just returned from China, where he has learned to concentrate. It is a valuable accomplishment--one which enables Clane to shut out of his mind absolutely ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The Wage Adjustment Board announced today that there will be no extension beyond midnight tonight of its immunity period on penalties against payment of higher than approved wage rates in the building construction industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The state of the budget is cloudy, meaning there are some bright spots as well as dark. The greatest black area is that caused by the continuing high level of expenditures which still have some elasticity. To some, this aspect is so overwhelmingly important as to obscure the more encouraging developments.

DAWN was breaking over Tokyo. Across the shimmering bay the level rays of the sun fell on the charred rubble of the docks, the jagged masonry of the waterfront factories and the burned-out workers quarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--Irked by the manner in which the disposal of surplus radio and radar equipment has been handled, Maj. Gen. Robert McGowan Littlejohn, War Assets Administrator, today ordered "drastic changes" to speed up sales.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The possibility that the capital's army of lobbyists is already in violation of the new law regulating their activities was raised by Congressional aides today after a conference with Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Depublic, Aug. 10 (AP)--Terror gripped the population of the northern provinces of the Dominican Republic tonight following two new shocks today in the six-day series of earthquakes and tidal waves that left seventy-three persons dead and 20,000 homeless.

PARIS, Aug. 10-France announced today she had rejected the United States proposal for the economic merger in part of German occupation zones, and offered a compromise plan for coordinating economic activities in the four areas. France's compromise would create Allied bureaus dependent upon the Allied Control Council operating in Berlin.
The chapel of the Riverside Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Clark Lobenstine, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Carlyle Lobenstine of 1148 Fifth ...

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 10--The departure of Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, to attend the Paris Conference has been fixed tentatively for next Friday, it was learned today.

IN a recent motion picture a comedy sequence shows an obviously cultivated young woman making out very badly in the rehearsal of a song-and-dance act. Well, she is so inadequate in her attempt that the other performers laugh. Whereupon heartof-gold Durante yells: "Cut that cut! The rest of youse wouldn't do no better if you was educated like she is."

"A REVUE needs a unifying idea," says Harold Rome, while the shade of the late Florenz Ziegfeld goes into a tailspin. "The disconnected thrown-together patchwork revue of the old days has gone for good."

Since its formation in November, 1943, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has shipped 13,000,000 tons of supplies worth $2,937,000,000 to the stricken countries of the world. In addition to distributing food, clothing and medical, agricultural and industrial equipment, ...
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 10--A series of disorders provoked by radical political groups here is expected to mar the celebration of the first anniversary of the victory of the Allies over Japan.

PARIS, Aug. 10--The draft peace treaty with Italy was condemned by Italian Premier Alcide de Gasperi this afternoon in an impassioned plea before a plenary session of the Conference of Paris in Luxembourg Palace.

PLANDOME, L.I., Aug. 10-- Sensational golf by Willie Turnesa enabled him and his brother Mike, pro at the Knollwood Club in Westchester and several times Westchester open champion, to reach the final round of the sixth annual Metropolitan pro-amateur championship at the Plandome Golf Club today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (Delayed)-- On Wednesday Trud published an account of conditions at Krasy Luch mining area in the Don Basin.

HOLLY WOOD. THE labor situation in Hollywood, which was pacified a month ago by an interim agreement giving blanket 25 per cent minimum wage increases to all unions except actors, writers and directors, last week showed signs of renewed unrest.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10--California authorities were preoccupied this week with a problem which more than once has stumped Federal lawmakers: the gambling ship.

WILTON, Conn., Aug. 10--The marriage of Miss Eleanor Hale Dun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Walke Dun of Belden Hill, this community, to the Rev. William John Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Wolf of Hartford, took place here this afternoon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

More than 20,000 persons crowded into the Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear the Sigmund Romberg concert that had been postponed because of rain from Sunday night, July 21. Mr. Romberg conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a popular program of numbers by himself, Offenbach, Johann Strauss, Sousa, Jerome ...
THE first anniversary of the end of World War II will be observed this week by the networks and most independent stations.

THE 'camelephamoose"--to get that settled right off--is an animal combining salient features of the camel, elephant and moose, created more or less accidentally by an ex-sergeant as a design for an animal-cracker. Yes, animalcracker.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10--Donald McNeil, national champion from Oklahoma in 1940, and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, winner of the Southampton Bowl, will meet tomorrow in the final of the Eastern grass court championship at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

NORTH BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 10--Miss Berry Bonynge, daughter of Lieut. Col. Russell Bonynge, USA (retired), and Mrs. Bonynge of Bronxville, N.Y., was married here this afternoon to Wilder Graves Penfield Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Penfield of Montreal and Magog Meadows, Que.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10--Miss Mary Lee Fahnestock, daughter of Col. and Mrs. Snowden A. Fahnestock of this city and Washington, D.C., made her debut tonight at a small dance given here by her parents at their home, Ker Arvor.

NOW that Ina Claire is in town and formal contracts for her appearance in George Kelly's "The Fatal Weakness," are being drawn, it is possible to list the tentative order in which the Theatre Guild is planning to present its program.

A new turn in the months-long effort by Britain and the United States to work out a joins solution of the complex Palestine problem appeared last week to be imminent. Events in Washington, in London and in Palestine seemed to foreshadow a change in policy designed to bring a showdown in the effort to end present uncertainties.

Some British circles in New York expressed last night the belief that Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, guaranteeing the right of self-defense of all member nations irrespective of other Charter provisions, would justify moving British troops into Iran, if such action were deemed necessary.
THE 1946 Berkshire Festival and the seventh given at Lenox by Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra finishes this afternoon at Tanglewood.

ON the heels of the brilliant "Open City" there comes to light the exciting story of yet another group of Italian film experimentalists led by young anti-Fascists, Luciano Emmer, his wife, Tatinia Grandino, and Enrico Gras.

NEWS out of London concerning the American show at the Tate Gallery has been pretty sparse this summer. In the issue of June 30 these columns carried an account based on such critical overseas comment as had been received at that time.

WHETHER you are one of those folks who buy their books by weight or by contents, you are sure to be satisfied with this book. It is very large, but the kind one likes to have large. The type is clear, the spacing is good, the decorations by Henry Pitz are suited to the subjects. In addition, there are 1,000 poems, the very poems you are looking for, old and new.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 10-- Ted Fritsch, who hopped to the Cleveland Browns of the All-America Conference, rejoined the Green Bay Packers today and Coach E.L. (Curly) Lambeau said there "absolutely had been no deal" with the rival league on a player exchange.

NUREMBURG, Germany, Aug. 10 (U.P.)--Field Marshal Erich von Manstein, who commanded German armies in Russia from 1941 to 1944, told the war crimes tribunal today that Adolf Hitler was compelled to attack Russia because the Soviet Union was planning to invade Germany.

Five treaties have been filed with the United Nations and the Secretariat is now preparing recommendations to the General Assembly under which these and other treaties will be registered with the United Nations before they may be invoked in any of its organs, it was learned yesterday.

The forty-second annual convention of the National Food Brokers Association will be held the week of Jan. 12, 1947, at Atlantic City, N.J.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11--The bakery strike which went into effect yesterday has slashed 1,000,000 loaves from the normal daily supply of the Philadelphia metropolitan district, leaving an estimated 500,000 loaves to be apportioned among about 3,000,000 residents.
LONDON, Aug. 11--Although experiencing the customary decline in business during the holiday season, the stock markets here are maintaining very good tone.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)-- With only ten States still to hold primaries and conventions, war veterans have won nominations for seven Senatorships, nineteen House seats and four Governorships.

World peace depends on "a humanity that does the right thing willingly," the Rev. Dr. Philip S. Watters, president of Drew Seminary for Young Women, said yesterday in a sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--The Federal Works Agency said today that it was ready to receive the applications of colleges and universities for aid in constructing educational facilities authorized by the Mead Act.

The United States should call for an international convention to develop a policy on cartels, it is declared by Edward S. Mason, of the Graduate School of Public Administration, Harvard University, in a study prepared for the Committee of Economic Development, released today.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 (AP)--Governor Dewey will open a three-day tour of normally stanch Republican territory tomorrow, beginning at Binghamton, and will appear at a clambake, a county fair opening and a victory day parade before returning to Albany Thursday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11-- The Stamford Yacht Club's fiftysixth annual regatta, which also was the fifteenth of the Long Island Sound Y.R.A. championship series, attracted 132 craft to- ...

VIENNA, Aug. 11--The Soviet Union threw away its chance of blocking Austrian nationalization of Soviet-held Austrian industries by the recent order of the Soviet command transferring those industries to Soviet ownership, a United States representative said today.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 11--W.R. Howe and John Humm Jr., Rockville, turned back J.H. Howe and Fred Lazard, Woodstock, N.Y., 5 and 3, in the final of the twelfth annual Arthur Man Memorial member-guest tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 11--Soon every foreigner in China will have a little card entitling him to live in the city in which he has taken up residence.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)--The White Sox defeated the Tigers twice today, taking the first game, 3 to 0, from Hal Newhouser, and winning the second game, 4 to 3, in twelve innings before 29,030 fans.

BOSTON, Aug. 11--Sid Cordon's fourth home-run of the campaign sank over the distant right field fence at Braves Field this afternoon with two mates aboard to save the Giants from the ignominy of a complete rout at the hands of Billy Southworth's rejuvenated Braves.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP)--The State Health Department said today that 232 cases and twenty-one deaths from diphtheria reported in New York State so far this year were the highest since 1934.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11--The Berkshire music center's eventful season came to a close at Tanglewood this afternoon amid the tumultuous applause of 12,000 persons, a record for this ninth year of the festival. This makes a total attendance for the festival itself of fully 88,500.

PARIS, Aug. 11--The United States delegation to the Conference of Paris is fully determined to remain here until the twenty-onenations meeting is over and the actual treaties have been drawn up by the Council of Foreign Ministers.

The Rev. John A. Langton, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Highland Falls, N.Y., and former rector of the Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at West Point, died here yesterday morning in St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. His age was 61.
An increase in the number of veterans with "civilian-connected disabilities" was disclosed yesterday in the quarterly report of the New York City Veterans Service Centers.
Stadium Concerts' new policy of scheduling only five concerts a week instead of seven, resulted in a total of thirty-eight concerts in the eight-week season. More than 300,000 persons attended.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Philadelphia and Washington divided a doubleheader today, the Senators winning the opener, 3--1, on Bobo Newsom's seven-hit pitching, but dropping the second, 12 to 5. It was Newsom's tenth victory of the season.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Monday, Aug. 12--Officially confirming receipt of a Soviet note on the Turkish Straits, a Governmental spokesman in Ankara declared early today that the Cabinet had been in session thirty-six hours and was "preparing an answer." He expected this to be ready tomorrow.

THERE was a very disturbing item from Europe in the papers the other day--not that the papers aren't full of disturbing items from Europe--but this happened to pertain to sport. It related that there seemed to be a concerted action on the part of many European nations to overthrow the classic definition of amateurism for the Olympic Games.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 11--Slowly but surely technical objections to reopening of Amsterdam trade in American securities are being wiped out, and it is hoped that these transactions soon will be resumed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 11 --City leaders are ready to go ahead with plans to convert the historic 92-year-old Absecon Lighthouse into a permanent museum and its 350 by 275 foot site into a park with recreational facilities, now that President Truman has signed the bill giving this city title to the property.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Aug. 11 (AP)--Three occupants of a Navy twin-engined Beechcraft and the pilot of a single-engined Aeronca trainer were killed today when the two airplanes crashed a few hundred feet over the Chesapeake (Ohio) airport and plummeted to earth on an Ohio river bank.
With the primary election a week from tomorrow, supporters of candidates having contests are increasing their activity, particularly for candidates for Congressional nominations.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11--Less activity prevailed in the cash lard market last week, although a fairly good volume of business was reported at 35 cents a pound early ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Justified increases in ceiling prices will be granted by the Office of Price Administration just as rapidly as it can act, Paul A. Porter, Price Administrator, said today.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11--Unusual British troop movements around the port of Haifa and the arrival of four British Navy landing craft converted into cages with supplies of barbed wire gave rise today to rumors that "floating detention camps" might
The Philadelphia pair of Charles J. Solomon and Sidney Silodor won the masters' pair event in the national contract bridge championship yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Enforcement agents of the War Assets Administration are looking into 374 complaints that veterans have misused their GI priorities to obtain war surplus property for private business concerns.
Speaking of "fear gripping our hearts" that the efforts of "the greatest minds in the world" at the Paris Conference may not achieve lasting world peace, Msgr. Walter P. Kellenberg, Assistant ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 11--A record corn crop is in sight, a Department of Agriculture report suggesting a yield of 3,497,000,000 bushels as of Aug. 1, or about 290,000,000 bushels above the previous record established in 1944 and 480,000,000 bushels more than last year.
A three-alarm fire yesterday afternoon in two drydocks of the Brighton Marine Repair Yard of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western...

TOKYO, Aug. 11--Fear that United States occupation won't last long enough to save Japan from Russian political and economic inroads was expressed by Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan in an interview in his official residence today.

The new Holland-America liner Westerdam is due to arrive at Fifth Street, Hoboken, at 8:30 A.M. today on her second voyage from Rotterdam. She carries 156 passengers and her cargo includes the first shipment of tulip bulbs to be sent here from the Netherlands this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--In "immediate prospect" as United States sea weapons are pilotless aircraft capable of carrying atomic bombs, the Navy revealed today. The disclosure was made in a report on the program for development of guided missiles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--In a move which was interpreted here as setting the groundwork for international trade negotiations, including discussions for reciprocal ...

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 11 (AP)-- Frank Stranahan of Toledo won the Western Amateur Golf championship today by defeating Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., in a par-breaking-38-hole battle over the Northland Country Club course.
Robert Hall's Nimrod III was the winner of the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight race to Cornfield Lightship and back.

Efforts to obtain a complete version of the Soviet plan for international atomic control will be renewed this week at meetings of the scientific and technical committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, it was learned yesterday.

Four thousand licensed merchant marine officers are badly needed for shipping schedules in the next six months, according to the War Shipping Administration, which announced that the shortage of trained marine engineers was now critical.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Coming from behind in both contests, the tail-end Pirates edged the Cubs, 10 to 9, in the first game of their doubleheader today ...
Eight hundred persons combined a visit to the animals at the Bronx Zoo with a check on their health yesterday as they lined up to have chest X-ray tests made at the mobile ...
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 11-- Capt. Edgar H. Pendleton, whose forty-four years as captain of Long Island Sound passenger craft included taking the Colonial ...

ATHENS, Ala., Aug. 11 (AP)-- Guardsmen remained under "alert" orders today and fifty highway patrolmen policed Athens to prevent repetition of race rioting which drove all Negroes off the streets with some knocked down and beaten.
During July sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 33.4 per cent over the like period of 1945, according to a compilation made over ...
The West 170th Street Realty Corporation has bought the three apartment houses at 617, 623 and 629 West 170th Street from Charles and Leo Levy, doing business as Levy Brothers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11--A United States C-47, flying from Vienna to Udine, and carrying eight military men and two civilians, was forced down in the vicinity of Ljubljana by Yugoslav fighter planes in Yugoslav territory, Aug. 9.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11--Prof. N. Priorov, Vice Minister of Public Health, moved by "many signs" of "irresponsible" care of patients in Russian hospitals, has demanded that hospitals be put into "proper order and conditions be created for qualified medical treatment."

MOSCOW, Aug. 11--Prof. N. Priorov, Vice Minister of Public Health, moved by "many signs" of "irresponsible" care of patients in Russian hospitals, has demanded that hospitals be put into "proper order and conditions be created for qualified medical treatment."

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 11 (U.P.)--Slight earth tremors shook this island today for the seventh successive day as the week-long casualty toll continued to mount and another small village on the north coast was reported destroyed by Thursday's tidal wave.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10--Soap manufacturers today declared that supplies of natural and synthetic fats and oils for soap production were near pre-war levels and urged that quota controls, which now restrict the amount of fats and oils they may use, be lifted at once.

LONDON, Aug. 11--Extracts from German documents in the archives of the German Foreign Ministry, saying that Turkey "passionately" wanted to see the Soviet Union annihilated by Germany during the war and citing her readiness before the invasion of Russia to conclude a friendship treaty with Germany were published today in the Russian newspaper Pravda.

Miss Burnice E. Fussell, nutritionist of the Greenwich (Conn.) Tuberculosis and Health Association, Inc., contends that in all the studies of diets undertaken recently no one has investigated the food habits of professional women, especially those living alone.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Harry Block, international vice president of the CIO-United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, said today that delegates from ten of eleven union districts throughout the community had voted to call on the union rank and file to oust all officers of communistic leanings.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11-- This is truly a wonderful country, unmatched throughout the world. For, where else but here can a rail-sputter--become President, a ...

Warning that racial intolerance and economic injustice in the world today are giving Russia a chance to spread communist doctrines among downtrodden peoples, the Rev. Dr. Herrick B. Young, secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, called yesterday for a "Christian global strategy."

OGUNQUIT, Me., Aug. 12--A new play, "Balloon," by Padriac Colum, Irish playwright and poet, began a week's trial run at the Ogunquit Playhouse here tonight before a capacity audience of summer colony first-nighters. The author was among them.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 12 (UP)--Effective defense of the Panama Canal against atomic bombs, rockets and robot planes requires close military cooperation with Latin-American nations and strict control over a radius of 1,000 miles from the Canal, in the opinion of Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, Gen. Hubert R. Harmon, and Adm. John F. Shafroth.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)--Stan Musial, the National League's leading hitter, collected three singles and a double for a perfect day at bat today as the Cardinals blanked the Cubs, 5--0. Musial, who has pounded out twelve hits in his last fourteen times at bat in three games, still wasn't the entire show in the Cardinals' fifth straight victory.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 12 (AP)-- Taking command as the field hit the stretch turn, Mrs. R.C. Hodges' Oxford Blue, 4-year-old son of Rhodes Scholar, won his third straight race at Rockingham Park today when he captured the $3,500 unity allowance purse by a length and a half.
Russia expressed formal opposition yesterday to the admission of Ireland and Trans-Jordan to membership in the United Nations.

Astragalinus tristis is a handsome, modest little fellow. This is the season of year when he and his peers are much in evidence. They add a bright spot of color as they fly over fields, gardens and pastures with their distinctive and peculiar undulations.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP)--The first twilight-night doubleheader of a major league season is scheduled to start at 6 P.M. (C.D.T.) here tomorrow between the White Sox and the Browns, currently trying to push each other into seventh place.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12-- After a three-year lapse, Newport, the cradle of the national championship, came back into the tennis picture today with the revival of the annual invitation tournament at the casino.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--The specter of returned black markets and rationing despite bumper crops was raised today as the new three-member Price Decontrol Board, facing the public for the first time, heard appeals from farm, trade, manufacturing, milling, exporting and cooperative...

Miss Teresa R. Herring, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert C. Herring of 15 East Seventyseventh Street and Lawrence, L.I., will be married on Sept. 28 to Louis S. Weeks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Weeks of this city and Briarwood Crossings, Lawrence.
Cotton futures displayed considerable irregularity yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and prices declined 16 to 75 points net on the day.

The four-story building containing twenty apartments at 3010 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn, was sold by Fannie Freedman and Rose Lepotkin to investing clients of M. John Miller, attorney, through Arthur Miles and Edward Ford, brokers in the transactions. The Home Title Guaranty Company insured the title.

While the Conference of Paris is getting down to work on the peripheral European peace treaties amid constant bickering between Russia and the western democracies, another and even morn important struggle is taking place over the central issue of European and world peace--Germany.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 12 (AP) --The Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, announced tonight that the Congress party had accepted an invitation to make proposals for the formation of a Government to rule India until a Constitution was framed.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 12--They Dutch people do not seek a peace of revenge, but hope Germany never again will be able to start an aggressive war, Dr. Jan H. van Royen, former Netherlands Minister of Foreign Affairs, declared today as he and 155 other passengers aboard the Holland-American Line motor vessel Westerdam arrived at 8:30 A.M. at the Fifth Street pier here.

LONDON, Aug. 12--Industrial shares again were the feature on the stock exchange here today. Dunlops was in demand and steel and colliery shares likewise were favored. Tobaccos were better and most stores made fresh headway.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Robert E. Wilson, chairman, and A.W. Peake, president, announced today that Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and subsidiaries earned $35,089,551, equal to $2.30 per share in the first half of 1946.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 12--The most important case involving former German property in Central America has just impelled the Government here to resort to Congressional action to nullify a court decision. The decision set a precedent by which many known Nazi sympathizers and their heirs could resume large-scale operations on properties seized under the laws of war.

GENEVA, Aug. 12--In search of a formula that will harmonize the divergent views of the nations that want to wind up the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, turning its work over to the United Nations, and those that want to continue its relief work, its Council set up a subcommittee on future policy today.

PARIS, Aug. 12--The nations of the world represented at the peace conference had the spectacle today of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Vice Foreign Minister, fighting for the right of freedom of speech against Secretary of State James F. Byrnes, who was the conference chairman.

PARIS, Aug. 12--Russia's campaign of political pressure on her satellites in eastern Europe and on Sweden, Spain and Greece has been notably intensified lately, according to diplomatic observers who are extremely well informed on those countries, it was learned today.

The year 1946 promises to be the first $1,000,000,000,000 year of check payments in the history of this or any other country, according to a calculation of the New York State Bankers Association. High as the $28,000,000,000 of this country's money circulation may seem to many citizens, it cannot...

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 12 (AP) --Russian "fifth-column" workers are spreading confusion throughout the world to allow the Soviet Union to consolidate its position in world affairs, former President Herbert Hoover said today.

Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations, looking ruddy and refreshed after a five-week sojourn in Europe, declined yesterday to discuss the possible postponement of the meeting of the General Assembly, scheduled for Sept. 23 at Flushing Meadow.

Mayor William O'Dwyer called a special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday for 10:30 Thursday morning to vote on the recommendation of Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander for immediate use of five lots and the grounds of one unused school as parking spaces for 1,700 vehicles a day in midtown Manhattan.

Capt. Arthur P. Cronin, who abandoned the damaged freighter American Farmer at sea on July 31, admitted before a Coast Guard investigating board here yesterday that he had not examined his ship below the main deck before leaving her, but asserted that his belief that the vessel was sinking was supported the next day by officers of a rescue craft.

War plants erected solely to expand wartime production, and which were thought certain by the contractors to prove "white elephants" in the real estate market when they were turned back to the Government, are finding a read sale, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--President Truman today approved a bill establishing Battery Park in New York City as a national shrine to be known as Castle Clinton National Monument and thereby saved from possible demolition the landing place, in this country, of about 8,000,000 immigrants whose descendants have fought to preserve the common national heritage.

Two slaughtering corporations were accused yesterday by the Office of Price Administration of illegal price deals on 67,696,928 pounds of meat that nurtured wholesale and retail black markets for an entire year.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP)--Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, winner of three successive major grass court tennis championships in as many weeks, today won her first-round match in the nineteenth Essex Country Club women's invitation tournament.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 (U.P.)--A former American correspondent in China testified before the war-crimes tribunal today that two of the twenty-seven defendants on trial were directly linked with Japanese conquest and that one, in a 1932 interview, had freely predicted that the Mukden incident would extend to China.
In a quarter century of constructive effort the Port of New York Authority has developed a habit of success which promises an even wider expansion of regional activity in the years just ahead.

New demands for pay increases for radio operators on American merchant ships were submitted yesterday by the American Communications Association, CIO, at the first of a series of three arbitration hearings before James L. Fly, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, at the offices of the American Arbitration Association, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP)--The Russian press charged today that "unseemly maneuvers" were endangering the prestige of the peace conference, accused a "BritishAmerican bloc" of trying to control the conference, and criticized Britain, the United States and France for their stands on procedure.
VASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--A race between American and foreign shippers to get the rich Orient trade once monopolized by the Japanese was described today in testimony before the Maritime Commission.

Gerard D. Reilly, retiring as a member of the three-man National Labor Relations Board after a term of five years, makes recommendations for changes in the Wagner Act that deserve a hospitable hearing both because of their prima facie reasonableness and the intimate practical experience behind them.

The Headquarters Commission of the United Nations yesterday emphatically reaffirmed its intention of establishing a permanent home in the Westchester-Fairfield area, perhaps even in spite of opposition it might continue to encounter there.

John Foster Dulles, who was chairman of the international conference of the World Council of Churches held recently in Cambridge, England, disclosed yesterday that negotiations had been undertaken for a relationship with the Soviet Russian branch of the Greek Orthodox Church.
The evolution of campus blue jeans into neater, more feminine fashions was the theme of Saks 34th's "college knowledge fashion session" held yesterday at the store.

Predicting continued good business for the jewelry industry for the remainder of the year, C.I. Josephson Jr., of Moline, Ill., president of the American National Jewelers Association, declared in an interview in the WaldorfAstoria in connection with the opening of the forty-first annual convention of the association that he expected heavy jewelry buying...

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 12--Serge Soudeikine, distinguished RussianAmerican theatrical painter and designer, died in Nyack Hospital today. He had been brought here from Valley Cottage, where he had gone only today to visit the Tolstoi Foundation and became ill. His age was 60.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12--Two ships carrying about 1,300 Jewish would-be immigrants entered the port of Haifa today under British destroyer escort. The vessels had been intercepted in Palestine territorial waters.

William T. Pheiffer, former Republican Representative from the Sixteenth New York District, announced yesterday that he had been named campaign manager of a committee supporting party candidates for the House of Representatives in the twenty-four New York City Congressional Districts.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 12 --We covered the waterfront this week-end from Rye, N.Y., to the Cape Cod Canal, and while the anglers who put out in boats seemed to be having from fair to good luck, the casters were affected by rather spotty fishing.
New York dress manufacturers in the low-end field are finding it increasingly difficult to maintain their production in the face of unfavorable price regulations, it was pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Creation of a National Distribution Council, an unpaid advisory body with the primary aim of helping American industry improve its distribution capacity and efficiency, as announced today by Secretary of Commerce Henry A. Wallace.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12--A direct implication that the Soviet Union has advanced in atomic fission experimentation to the point where she has an atomic bomb ready for detonation came from a Russian scientist here today.
CHATTANTOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 12 (AP)--Edward H. Crump, Shelby County (Memphis) political leader, said in a half-page advertisement today that Tennessee...

If, as the cognoscenti would have us believe, the Dodgers are destined to crack, collapse in the face of a late Cardinal push, the time for such a backslide was ripe along about 4 o'clock yesterday at Ebbets Field. Not alone were the Brooks trailing the Giants by two runs, but the Cardinals, according to the scoreboard, were well on their way to victory over the Cubs.

ATHENS, Ala., Aug. 12 (AP)-- A special session of the grand jury next Monday was ordered today to investigate Saturday's race riot and Circuit Solicitor George C. Johnston said he would press for immediate trial of any persons indicted by the jury.

Even though its final assembly lines were able to work forty-nine days in the second quarter, compared to only nine days in the first quarter, the Packard Motor Car Company showed a consolidated net profit of $749,517 in the first half of 1946, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
MILAN, Italy, Aug. 12--The body of Benito Mussolini has been found in a trunk hidden in the Pavia Monastery near here and is now in police custody, a police statement said tonight.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations in the first half of 1946 resulted in a net deficit of $5,141,438, compared with a net income of $1,049,725 in the six months to June 30, 1945. Gross operating revenues declined $6,032,666, or 6.5 per cent, to $86,684,394.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 12 (AP)--Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt contended today before the International Military Tribunal that members of the Nazi High Command and General Staff never held with Hitler's theory that the Germans were "the master race."
A minor tempest over housing accommodations at Shanks Village was cleared up yesterday after it appeared for a while that something new in the technique of "tiein" renting had been developed.

MATANZAS, Dominican Republic, Aug. 12 (AP)--A sudden outbreak of disease capped the terror of earthquake and tidal wave on this Caribbean island today as upward of seventy-five persons were stricken with paratyphoid fever, malaria or intestinal ailments in a single camp of 500 refugees.

SCOTTSBORO, Ala., Aug. 12 (U.P.)--Disgruntled by the county's delay on road work, a group of farmers and veterans came down from the hills on Saturday, seized the county road machinery and started the work themselves, it was disclosed today.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 12--The statement by Gen. George C. Marshall and Ambassador John L. Stuart does not flatly announce the breakdown of efforts, with American participation, to promote a peaceful settlement between the Chinese Government and the Communists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--The Federal Government could wield the country's most powerful weapon against inflation by curbing its own expenditures, William K. Jackson, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 12--Senator Robert M. LaFollette is expected to prove in the Wisconsin primary election tomorrow that a man can bolt the Republican party and get away with it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--A select House committee began lifting the lid today on the record of the War Assets Administration's procedure in disposing of surplus property.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12--Five 3-year-olds ran the Wilson rule course in the $5,000 Saranac Purse at Saratoga today, and the only one among them not named for Saturday's Travers, A. C. Ernst's filly Aladear, won in a romp.
This is the sixth in a series of interviews with chefs of leading retsaurants in New York City, in which each tells how to make one of his specialties. The seventh will appear next week.

"Important and startling information" about the Ku Klux Klan, including plans for joint antiAmerican activity by leaders of the Klan and the defunct GermanAmerican Bund from 1941 to this year, was obtained by Assistant Attorney General Daniel Duke of Georgia during his visit in New York, he said yesterday.
Diwan Chaman Lal, member of the Central Legislative Assembly of India and head of the Indian Food Mission to Argentina, is in New York.

President Ford Frick of the National League yesterday sent Mickey Owen's application for reinstatement into organized baseball back to Cincinnati, where Commissioner Albert B. (Happy) Chandler alone will decide whether the 30-year-old catcher should be given another chance with the Dodgers, according to The United Press.

Details of the plan by which certain brand-name products may again be shipped to the United Kingdom in "token" quantities, were announced yesterday by L.L. Horch, regional director of the New York office of the Department of Commerce.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12-- In what was reported to be its last scheduled meeting with local officials, the United Nations Headquarters Commission here today heard objections from officials of Stamford, Greenwich and North Castle on the revised ten-mile site affecting their communities.

LONDON, Aug. 12--The British Government announced today that no more unscheduled immigration into Palestine would be allowed and that would-be immigrants would in the future be taken to Cyprus "and elsewhere" until their future was decided.
PARIS, Aug. 12--Albania, Mexico, Cuba and Egypt were invited by the peace conference today to appear and make known their feelings about the proposed Italian peace treaty.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 12 --Governor Dewey, in a series of speeches here today, indicated that his campaign for re-election this fall would be based on two main points. One is a plea that he be allowed to complete the $1,000,000,000 institutional and road building program begun in his first...

MASON WADE, author of a distinguished biography of Parkman, "Francis Park man: Heroic Historian," has been at work for several years upon an exhaustive account of the French Canadians. Knowing that the scholarly apparatus of his proposed book would make it completely indigestible to all but a few, Mr. Wade has prepared what his publishers call an...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--A United States compromise plan to end Arab-Jewish strife in Palestine was reported unofficially to have reached President Truman's desk today.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 12 (U.P.) --Hooper Triplett has been banished from the Columbus Cardinals on charges that he wagered $20 his team would lose to Columbia, S.C., in a Sally League game Aug. 3, it was revealed today.

The United States Department of Agriculture has forecast record wheat and corn crops. It also points out that we are entering a period in which there will be a seasonal expansion of food supplies. Meat supplies are expected to be larger than last fall. It will be recalled that supplies at that time were so large that meat rationing was discontinued.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--The American Federation of Labor condemned the record of the Seventyninth Congress on social legislation today as "dismal" and laid plans for an intensive program of political action.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Retail price ceilings of all passenger automobiles were raised an average of $82 today to meet requirements of the new price-control act, and a further increase is expected.

Retail automobile dealers in the Metropolitan district were bewildered yesterday by the increases in price ceilings ordered by the OPA on automobiles of all makes. With a further increase presaged, they said they would sell the cars at the new rates, subject to any future increases.

WASHINGTON, August 12-- Perturbed by any circumstances that would curtail the free flow of news during the present critical international situation, Government officials today kept a close watch on developments in the press embargo's of the American Communications Association.

After conferring at City Hall yesterday with a group of union officials on their proposals for higher pay for members of the Sanitation Department, Mayor O'Dwyer said he would appoint an official to survey the situation and make recommendations to him.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 12-- Princeton University's head football coach, Charles W. Caldwell Jr., will put a squad of seventy through three weeks of intensive pre-term training starting Sept. 3, it was announced here today by Assistant Athletic Director Howard W. Stepp.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 12 (Reuter)--Politicians and foreign diplomats in Teheran were predicting today that "something may happen any minute" as tension rose following Prime Minister Ahmad Ghavam's ban on political activities among members of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--United States recognition of the revolutionary Government of Bolivia, which came into power on July 21 after a bloody upheaval, was announced today by Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson. The revolution cost the lives of about 200 persons and injuries to about 400 more.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 12 --With a split-second finish between the first two to arrive, the New York Yacht Club fleet came here today on its initiial cruise run, that of twenty-four miles from Sarah Ledge gang buoy at the entrance of New London Harbor to the breakwater bell off Great Salt Pond.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 12--New Jersey's revenues from its threecent-a-gallon gasoline tax in the first six months of 1946 were reported today by the State Petroleum Industries Committee to be near the high record set in the first half of 1941 before war intervened to curb highway travel.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 12-- The contents of the Russian note on the Turkish straits, handed to Turkey a few days ago, were revealed today by a Turkish personality close to the highest Government circles.

A new "kid sister" army of USO hostesses has been enlisted to entertain the new "kid brother army" of 18-year-old recruits, it was announced yesterday at United Service Organizations headquarters in the Empire State Building.

A tanners' industry advisory committee meeting scheduled for Thursday in Washington with the Office of Price Administration, was canceled yesterday by Frank H. Miller, chairman. In telegrams to the committee members Mr. Miller, of G. Levor Co., pointed out that deliveries of domestic hides might be hindered by expectations of some raw stock dealers...

While there have been no positive indications in the last two weeks as to what steps, if any, the insurance industry and lending institutions will take following the recent reduction by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York of interest rates on policy loans, reaction to Mutual's "lonewolf" move has been somewhat paradoxical.

The war veterans of McMinn County, Tenn., who won their first political battle with gunfire, appear now to have decided to continue their fight for honest elections and clean government with less drastic means.

BERLIN, Aug. 12--United States Army criminal investigation agents said today that they had uncovered a multimillion dollar, world-wide black market ring operated by a single New York family with sons in Berlin, Paris and Shanghai.

PARIS, Aug. 12--Czechoslovakia has made overtures to France for the conclusion of treaty of friendship and mutual assistance something like that which proved unavailing at Munich, but the French Government is disinclined to take any such action at this time, according to one of its official spokesmen.
SALEM, Mass., Aug. 12 (U.P.)-- Thomas Henry Brown, 29 years old, a discharged combat soldier, called police to his home today and informed them that he had strangled his mother--"with my bare hands."

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Heavy short covering developed in oats and corn futures in late trading on the Board of Trade today, disclosing a lack of pressure, and the close was about the top with oats up 2 to 2 cents a bushel and corn 2 1/8 cents. Feed barley futures gained cent, but the market was entirely nominal, no sales being reported.

For the first time in its history the Red Cross now feels that it should work on an international basis, not alone to save men after disaster has struck, but to prevent the greatest disaster of all--war, Basil O'Connor, chairman of the League of Red Cross Societies and the American Red Cross, reported yesterday on his return from overseas.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 (AP)--Yugoslav authorities held incomunicado today the occupants of a United States C-47 Army transport plane that was forced down near Ljubljana by Yugoslav fighters last Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12-- Registration statements covering 76,000 shares of capital stock, 80,529 shares of class A stock and 173,959 shares of common stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange CommiSSion today by three companies.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP)--A pair of champions--Miss Phyllis Otto of Atlantic, Iowa, and Miss Louise Suggs of Lithia Springs, Ga.--shot one-under-par 75's today to tie for the medal in the eighteen-hole qualifying round of the women's Western amateur golf championship tournament.

Reflecting a sharp rise in gross sales, the Celanese Corporation of America reported yesterday for the first half of 1946 a consolidated net profit of $3,644,686 above that for the first six months of 1945. The report is scheduled to be mailed today to stockholders.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP)--The racing silks of G.R. Watkins, sheriff of Delaware County, Pennsylvania, were carried to a popular victory by Cat Bridge in the mile and a furlong Seashore Purse, feature race at the Atlantic City track today.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 12--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James T. Phillips of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Dudley, to Robin Van Dusen Finnesey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Browne Finnesey of near-by Short Hills.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (U.P.)-- The death toll from infantile paralysis in Minneapolis and St. Paul reached eighty-five today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Commissioner Lowell B. Mason, who is President Truman's man on the Federal Trade Commission, wrote another one of his unorthodox opinions today. This time he charged all four of his colleagues with "attempting to settle a private struggle between enterprises by opening a Pandora's Box of governmental directives."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--President Truman decided today against Federal seizure of the farm implement plants of the J.I. Case Company, which have been struck since last October.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 12 (AP) --Midwest Stables of Du Quoin pulled down the major portion of the honors today as Grand Circuit harness racing returned to the Illinois State Fair Grounds after a wartime lay-off.

Andy Shaw of the Pomonok Club in Flushing took the opening-day lead in The World-Telegram holein-one tournament at the Bayside golf links yesterday, hitting the ball 1 foot 9 inches from the pin with his third of five shots.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 12--Attacking the method of selecting blue ribbon panels as tending to create "rigged juries," Harold R. Medina, attorney for Joseph S. Fay, Newark labor leader convicted of extortion and conspiracy by such a jury, moved today for a review of the case by the United States Supreme Court.

Mary Smieton, the United Nations' personnel director, presided yesterday over a meeting to establish a single international civil service for the United Nations and its specialized agencies.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 13 (AP) --Representative William J. Gallagher of Minnesota, who came from relative political obscurity to win a seat in Congress after being pensioned from his job as a city street cleaner, died here today of a chronic liver ailment. His age was 71.

Six sales reported in the Greenwich Village section of Manhattan focused realty attention on that area yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 14-- The Fresh Meadov Country Club today put its sumptuous new layout at Lake Success on display with a pro-member golf event in which forty of the leading metropolitan district's experts, including three former national open champions, Craig Wood, Johnny Farrell and Tony Manero, each teamed with three members in an eighteenhole, best-ball tourney.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--For "meritorious services" rendered in connection with the training program for Chinese air cadets, thirtyseven United States Army officers were honored today by the Government of China with decorations conferred on them in its name and on its behalf by its Ambassador in Washington, Dr. V.K. Acting Capt. Frederick F.E. Zwirz, the Police Department's oldest fingerprint expert, has applied for retirement, it was learned yesterday. He is one of 141 members of the department whose applications will be considered by the board of trustees of the Department's Pension Fund tomorrow at police headquarters.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 14--Joe McCarthy is back in the headlines out here in Wisconsin, only this time it's politics, not baseball.

Firmly convinced that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's grip on Spain is weakening by the day, Spanish Republican leaders in New York are conducting an intensive public and behind-the-scenes campaign to get the Security Council to apply the economic sanctions they believe will unseat him entirely.
A nation-wide campaign to organize registered graduate nurses into the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes Union, AFL, was started last night.

PARIS, Aug. 14--A strong plea for "justice" for Hungarian minorities in Rumania and Czechoslovakia was made today by Janos Gyongyosy, Foreign Minister of Hungary, in an address before a plenary session of the Conference of Paris.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 14 --The negotiations for a new Anglo-Egyptian military alliance unexpectedly came to life today when Egyptian Ambassador Abdul Fattah Amr Pasha brought from London what Premier Tsmail Sidky called new treaty "formulas."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Tex Hughson held the Philadelphia Athletics to four scattered hits as the Boston Red Sox picked on Dick Fowler for eleven safeties and a 3-to-1 victory today, before 13,733 ladies' day and school children fans. It was the Sox' thirteenth victory in fifteen games with the Mackmen.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 275,000 barrels, reversing the downward trend for the past several months, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 87,016,000 barrels, against 86,741,000 at the end of the previous week and 86,414,000 on Aug. 11, 1945.
Poland demanded yesterday that the application of Trans-Jordan for membership in the United Nations be deferred for one year lest any "hasty decision" complicate the "tragic problem" of Palestine.

An issue of $1,000,000 of Sacramento County, Calif., Sanitation District No. 1 sewer system and treatment plant bonds dated July 1 and due on July 1, 1947 to 1966, has been acquired by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates at 100.0509 as 2s, 2 s and 2 s at an average interest cost to the county of 2.377 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--A B-28 Superfortress landed here this afternoon, completing a threemonth mission of winging between Canada and Peru in pursuit of information about the cosmic ray.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14(AP)-- Prison sentences of the first two enlisted men convicted in the Lichfield trials were suspended by the Army today to equalize their punishment with that of convicted officers.

Manager Bill Dickey's prize young right-hander encountered no such difficulties against the Senators.

CLEVELAND. Aug. 14 (AP)-- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., was wishing tonight she had "stuck to golf and never taken up the game of pool" during off hours at the women's Western amateur golf championship tournament here.

The master of the freighter Benjamin Goodhue, which picked up the personnel of the abandoned American Farmer at sea and brought them to port here last Saturday, said yesterday that the Farmer's captain told him his collision-damaged vessel had sunk.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--The Price Decontrol Board received a warning from the National Wage Stabilization Board today that it could not hold the line on wages unless the prices of essential foods were recontrolled and rolled back to levels as close to those of June 30 as the new OPA law would allow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--An effort by world Zionism to convert the British blockade of unauthorized Jewish immigrants to Palestine into a twelve-nation challenge of the validity of such restrictions was disclosed by its spokesmen here today.

The leading hole-in-one expert for the 1946 season in the thirteenth annual World-Telegram competition is Frank Majer Jr., of Flushing, who turned in the winning shot of one and one-half inch during the second day of competition on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--Benjamin Franklin Fields, Washington surplus property broker, received today a "last warning" to produce subpoenaed office records or face contempt proceedings. Recovering early losses, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 23 points higher to 7 points lower following a day of erratic fluctuations.

The Columbia Gas Electric Corporation and subsidaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $20,118,881 for the twelve months ended June 30, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.12 a share for 12,223,256 common shares, comparing with $14,052,734, or 62 cents a common share, for the preceding year. CINCINNATI, Aug. 14-- Mickey Owen, the former Brooklyn catcher, must pay the full penalty of five years suspension from organized baseball for hopping to Mexico, the baseball commissioner's office ruled today.

New York City observed the first anniversary of victory over Japan without conspicuous ceremony yesterday. For most people it was just another day and last year's V-J day, when New York was alive with shouts of joy and blowing of horns, was merely a memory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--When Poland let the United States have copies of her trade agreements with neighboring countries last week she did so on the understanding that they were to be regarded as secret, State Department officials explained today.

PARIS, Aug. 14--Bulgaria's claim to be recognized as a co-belligerent, to be relieved of all or part of her reparation obligations and to obtain Western Thrace from Greece was presented to the Conference of Paris today. In this bid Bulgaria was supported by Poland and the Ukraine, but vigorously opposed by Premier Constantin Tsaldaris on behalf of Greece.

The bland potato, its importance to whisky-makers increased more than a hundredfold within a year, is packing a lively punch into tavern talk and verandah conversations these summer evenings.

STEAMBOAT JOHNSON is an autocratic and colorful character who umpires in the South ern League, a job he has had for more than a quarter of a century. They call him "the Bill Klem of the minors" and it's a rather apt designation. On one occasion the brassy-voiced Steamboat rendered a decision against a home-town team and the fans were furious.

First steps in a $120,000,000 financing plan by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation were taken yesterday when the company registered an issue of 1,647,037 additional common shares, representing about $40,000,000 and a new issue of $30,000,000 of debentures with the Securities and Exchange Commission. WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-Retail prices for twenty classes of consumer durable goods upon which, according to Government spokesmen, the public spends an estimated $2,500,000,000 to $3,000,000,000 annually were increased 3 to 12 per cent today by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Sept. 3 --A squad of seventy-three candidates for the Yale football eleven participated in the opening season of the Elis' ten-day conditioning program which began at the Gunnery School here today. Morning and afternoon workouts were held and a double session schedule will be adhered to until the squad returns to New Haven on Saturday, Sept. 14.

Moriz Rosenthal, the eminent Polish pianist, died last night in his apartment at the Hotel Great Northern. He had not been in good health for several years, but had been confined to bed only a week. His age was 83.

Pushing dollar volume to a new high record for the month, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 61 per cent in August over the corresponding month of last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In July, sales had shown a rise of 40 per cent.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 3--The first Chinese move to take over United States war surpluses with an original cost of more than $800,000,000 was made here today when a seven-man group from the Executive Yuan's Board of Supplies flew to Okniawa to handle the first lot of bulk purchases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today closed its program of voluntary non-governmental contributions of cash and commodities under which more than $150,000,000 worth of relief supplies has been sent into countries devastated by war and famine.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 54 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the gain was 47...

Broadway shakes off its summer lethargy tonight with the presentation of "The Front Page" at the Royale. It mill be a sort of reunion for first-nighters, who haven't bandied words with each other since the last opening brought them together on July 15. Eighteen years

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 --When Herschel Johnson, the United States representative on the Security Council, disapproved the habit of using the United Nations as a platform for national propaganda, he raised an ancient parliamentary problem that is easier to condemn than correct.

John Kramer of Montebello, Calif., William Talbert of Wilmington, Del., and Robert Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., took their places in the quarter-finals of the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and the defnding titleholder, Frank Parker from Beverly Hills, Calif., advanced to the fourth round with Herbert Flam of the same city.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 3--Liberally sprinkled with veterans from squads as far back as 1940, Cornell's football forces reported to Head Coach Ed McKeever today for fall practice and went through two fast workouts.

PARIS, Sept. 3--Soviet Vice Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishin sky threw a bombshell into the Finnish Political and Territorial Commission at the Conference of Paris this evening by challenging France's right to vote in that commission on the ground that she had not been at war with Finland.

ROME, Sept. 3--Italian Government circles said today that reparations claims against Italy, amounting to about $27,000,000,000, represented more than Italy's present national wealth. They estimated the national wealth at $26,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--A denunciation by Governor Dewey of New York of the Federal Housing Authority has drawn from Wilson W. Wyatt, head of the National Housing Agency, a tart rejoinder in effect accusing the Governor of seeking to put the interests of New York State's home-seeking veterans above those of the rest of the country.

A one-man show was held at Stein Blaine's yesterday, with Muriel King the sole contributor. This designer demonstrated that she has got back into her New York stride after several years in Hollywood. Miss King exhibited her first collection for this house last spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--Senator James M. Mead of New York said today that he would ask the Senate War Investigating Committee, which he heads, to invite Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King, wartime Chief of Naval Operations, to ap-...

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 4-- Almost unanimously London theatre critics found that Frederick Lonsdale's "But for the Grace of God," which opened last night at the St. James Theatre, belonged to a by-gone day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--The United States Government disputed tonight a new Yugoslav note charging that American planes had been deliberately violating Yugoslav sovereignty. The Belgrade note, dated Aug. 30, charged that infringements of Yugoslav territory were continuing.

BOSTON, Sept. 3--Umpire Jocko Conlan ruled Bill Rigney late in a headlong dive to third base trying for a force play as the tying run trickled over the plate for the Braves in their season's finale here with the Giants today. A moment later Tommy Holmes cleared the loaded bases with a double that chased Dave Koslo, who suffered his sixteenth setback, 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--Interest in politics is diminished only in quantity here by the absence of Congress, since politicians outnumber the practitioners of all other trades in the executive branch of the Government and are not unknown in the judicial arm. Therefore the conventions of the two major parties in New York State today were watched as closely as developments in the international field, and by many with a livelier sense of immediate personal concern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, in a radio address tonight, charged the Republican party with conducting a thirteenyear legislative sit-down in Congress. He asked the electorate of both parties to decide in the November elections whether the gains made under President Roosevelt were to be surrendered or retained.

PARIS, Sept. 3--Italian Fascist militiamen and members of Benito Mussolini's "Republican" forces may serve as officers or non-commissioned officers in the new Italian armed forces if they have been "exonerated by the appropriate body under Italian law," according to a recommendation accepted today by the Paris Conference's military commission.
PARIS, Sept. 3--The imminent visit of Secretary Byrnes to Germany stirs more interest in inner circles in Paris than anything that is happening in the Peace Conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP)-- Arthur Emlen Newbold Jr., member of a prominent Philadelphia family and a partner of Drexel Co., died today in a Bar Harbor, Me., hospital. His age was 58. He suffered a heart attack while on vacation at his summer home.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 3--As the deadline approached for the start of the school term tomorrow morning, the 236 teachers of the sixteen public schools of this city today stood fast on their strike for pay increases.

The creeping paralysis of the first general trucking strike in six years slowed down the city's commercial life yesterday and curtailed the movement of food, despite renewed assurances by Mayor O'Dwyer that there was no occasion for consumers to become pan icky.

One of the largest squads in his seventeen years at the helm of Columbia football greeted Coach Lou Little yesterday as the Lions began four weeks of two-a-day practice sessions at Baker Field. Seventy-one players, seventeen of them letter men from last year, started work for the first game with Rutgers here Sept. 28.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--The Office of Price Administration lifted price controls today from twenty-one additional construction and industrial materials, with an annual production value estimated at $110,000,000, which were deemed not essential to the Veterans Emergency Housing Program.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has opened its second annual meeting, at Copenhagen, under somewhat fairer skies than prevailed at its first meeting a year ago.

Greta Garbo and Lillian and Dorothy Gish of the screen and stage, and Mrs. James Forrestal, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, were among the 1,395 passengers who arrived here yesterday from Gothenburg on the Swedish-American liner Gripsholm, which docked at Pier 97, North River, at 9 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--President Truman today proclaimed Oct. 6 to 12 as Fire Prevention Week as the Chamber of Commerce of the United States estimated American fire losses at a new sixteen-year high with an average of 300,000 fires a year in homes alone.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3--Weakness in securities markets had relatively little effect on grains on the Board of Trade today.

PARIS, Sept. 3--Secretary of State James F. Byrnes will speak in Stuttgart on Friday, and he is expected to make clear that the United States does not intend to withdraw from Europe or disinterest itself in Europe.

A general maritime strike which might tie up all merchant vessels on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coasts, regardless of national flag, was called for tomorrow afternoon by the Seafarers International Union and the Sailors Union of the Pacific, both AFL affiliates, yesterday.

E.H. Bogardus, associated with the Tubize Rayon Corporation since 1925, has been named sales manager of the rayon division of Celanese Corporation of America.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Sept. 3 --A platform declaring that the way to industrial peace was "a maximum of mediation and conciliation rather than governmental interference and compulsion" was adopted without a single dissenting vote by the Republican State Convention here tonight.

PANAMA, Sept. 3--President Enrique A. Jimenez said today that any agreement for the occupation of defense sites by the United States in Panama would be negotiated only after sites now occupied had been returned.

American tin interests expect that the London metal industry will advance the price of tin purchased from Nigeria as soon as the signing of the United States and Bolivian Government contracts for the ensuing year has been formally announced, it was declared yesterday.

Net earnings of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., for the first six months of this year were $1,838,970, or 115 per cent more than the net of $856,788 in the corresponding half of 1945, Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, president and general manager, reported in the semi-annual...

MOSCOW, Sept. 3--A vast outpouring of national pride in the Red Army, Navy and Air Force and their "victory over imperialist Japan," as it was described by Premier Stalin in his order of the day, marked nationwide celebrations on the first anniversary of V-J Day in the Soviet Union today.

New York City's municipal and privately endowed colleges and universities will enroll 145,000 students this fall, making the metropolitan area's combined student body the largest in its history, a survey showed yesterday. Of the total, nearly 60,000 will be war veterans.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 3 (AP)--The International Olympic Committee has before it a proposal that a special winter Olympic championship be established in addition to the existent championship in combination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--Overtones of atomic problems facing the nation dominated today the opening exercises of the National War College, first American institution designed to achieve integration and understanding of military and foreign policies at the highest levels of the War, Navy and State Dapartments.

PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 4-- The Constituent Assembly in a long session approved early this morning a parliament of two houses as part of the new Constitution although only one house, the National Assembly, was provided with legislative powers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3--Because of its annoyance over American sympathy for Zionism, the Syrian Government has declined even to discuss oil and air transport agreements with the United States, authoritative quarters disclosed here today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Sept. 3 --The Republican party unanimously voted tonight to stand on the record of the Dewey Administration during the past four years in its platform for the 1946 State campaign.
The proprietors of fifty-four restaurants caught in the city Health Department's cleanup drive were fined a total of $4,815 yesterday by Magistrate Edward Thompson in Municipal Term Court.

PARIS, Sept. 3--A new article in the Rumanian peace treaty to protect the rights of Jews was proposed today to the Rumanian political and territorial commission by the United Kingdom delegation. It was a result of representations made to the Council of Foreign Ministers by Jewish organizations. Similar articles will probably be proposed for other peace treaties before the Paris conference.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 3 (U.P.)-- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, said today that "the Russians may have more than a spectator's interest in Indian affairs and they are not very far from India, either."

IT probably is just as well for Jack Kramer that his father wearied of playing catch with him a dozen years ago. The monotony of tossing a ball back and forth as a means of exercise palled on the father, who'd been something of a frustrated athlete himself.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3--Three companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering 150,000 shares of preferred stock and more than 100,000 shares of common stock.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox announced today that applications for World Series tickets will be accepted on and after Tuesday, Sept. 10.

Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., who has held the U.S. amateur golf crown since the last pre-war meet in 1941, tees off at 10:20 A.M. next Monday in the opening qualifying round of the 1946 meet at Baltusrol Country Club, at Springfield, N.J., The Associated Press reports.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 3 --Supreme Court Justice Charles W.U. Sneed reserved decision here today on a motion made by the New York City Corporation counsel's office for a change of venue from Westchester County to New York County of a suit brought by Westchester to invalidate the city's dictation of the amounts of milk that Westchester and ten other suburban counties may receive from six major distributors.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 3-- Jesus T. Pinero, the first nativeborn Puerto Rican to govern this island, was inducted into office today in a colorful ceremony as thousands stood massed before the Capitol steps.

The combination of the Canadian-owned Windfields and the Swedish-born Herb Lindberg was the winning one in the $5,000 Sil vet Lake Purse at Aqueduct yesterday, for they put on a frontrunning act before 20,989 more or less appreciative onlookers to gain a three-length decision.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP)--The Indians turned back the St. Louis Browns, 5--3 and 7--3, in a doubleheader before, a sparse crowd of 2,952 today and moved into a tie with Chicago for fifth place in the American League.

A message from Shanghai on Friday, that the little Chinese girl found by the United States Marines in the Solomons in January, 1943, had been identified by Mrs. Ruth Li as her daughter Patsy, believed lost in the bombing and sinking of a ship near Singapore in February, 1942, was confirmed yesterday in a letter from Mrs. Li at Vila, New Hebrides, where she reclaimed her daughter from an orphanage there.

ATHENS, Sept. 3 (AP)--Acting Premier Stylianos Gonatas said tonight that the pro-Monarchist Government would order emergency measures back into effect unless Communist bands stopped trying to "impose their will by force" on the country.

Supervision by a physician of well babies, as well as medical care of sick children, was added yesterday to the Federal service provided by the Emergency Medical and Infant Care Program (EMIC Plan) in this city, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein announced.

ALBANY, Sept. 3--Democratic hopes for victory in the State campaign, which once were high and then dropped to a record low level, have risen again as a result of the ticket selected by leaders of the party. All on the slate are scheduled for formal nomination, without a dissenting vote, at the final session of the State convention tomorrow.

Henry Lustig, president of the Longchamps restaurant chain, who was convicted six weeks ago of defrauding the Federal Government of nearly $6,000,000 in income taxes, was in more trouble with the authorities yesterday.

Formation of Monitor Sales, Inc., to act as distributor in the metropolitan area and in the State of Connecticut for the Monitor Equipment Company, was disclosed yesterday by George W. Nevin, president of the new company. The company has taken over the distributorship formerly held by Rex Cole, Inc.

Both the salmon fisherman and the surfcaster are gradually coming into their own these days, and most reports from the northern rivers and the popular beaches indicate that fish are not only larger but more plentiful.

LONDON, Sept. 3--Field Marshal Gen. Paul Ludwig Ewald von Kleist, former commander in chief of the Germany Army Group in Yugoslavia and on the Russian Front, now held as a prisoner of war in Britain, is to be handed over to Yugoslavia to stand trial for war crimes.
