LONDON, Sept. 3--The stock markets here generally remained quiet today, but gilt-edged issues were good again. Old Console closed strongly, while War Loan 3 s also rose. Argentine rails remained firm, and in foreign bonds demand continued for Far Eastern issues.

The nation's two-month draft holiday ended yesterday, but the resumption of New York's selective service machinery ground out just twenty-five inductees. Elsewhere in the country similar handfuls of men were called up as draft boards began contributing to a September quota of 25,000.

Henry James wrote some time before he died in 1916: "There are few hours in life more agreeable than the hour dedicated to the ceremony known as afternoon tea." Unhappily, few Americans know of what the novelist was talking.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 3 (U.P.)-- Moslem merchants began to flee Bombay tonight as violent HinduMoslem rioting spread and grew worse through the third straight day, sending the casualty toll climbing to 109 killed and 397 injured. It appeared to be more fully organized.
First signs of a meat shortage, which a Government official said would become "terrific," have made their appearance in the wholesale markets of this city, it was disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 3--Its delegates encouraged by the selection of what they regard as a strong and well-balanced ticket, the Democratic State Convention met today in the Tenth Regiment Armory and listened to speeches which made clear the issues on which the party would base its election campaign.

The American Labor party has decided to support the nominees of the Democratic party for Justice of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3--Protestant "Press Month" will be observed during October with the more than 200 journals affiliated with the Associated Church Press invited to participate, the Rev. T. Otto Nall president of ACP, announced here today.

So far as the New York State Athletic Commission is concerned, Marty Servo no longer is the welterweight boxing champion of the world. Eddie Eagan, chairman of the commission, yesterday declared the title vacant because Seivo, who claims a nose injury, refused to go through with his scheduled championship match against Ray Robinson at the Yankee Stadium on Friday night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3--Production of beef and pork came almost to standstill throughout the country today as the new ceilings of $20.25 a hundred pounds for cattle and $16.25 for hogs became effective. In the July-August free-trade period a peak of $30.25 was established for steers and $24.50 for swine.

BOSTON, Sept. 3--American determination to make a permanent world peace through the United Nations must be inexhaustible despite the rebuffs met on the international front, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the forty-seventh annual encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today.

There's a clash or openings tonight--"Yours Is My Heart" at the Shubert, and "A Flag Is Born" at the Alvin. In deference to the former, which announced its premiere first, the critics have been invited to review the second performance of "A Flag Is Born" tomorrow night.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 4--Tim Breslin, member of Crestmont and just back from four year's service with the Fourth Marine Division, today celebrated his return by setting the pace for a field of more than one hundred golfers competing in the twenty-third annual invitation tournament of the Arcola Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4--Encountering opposition of a sort they scarcely expected from Connie Mack's eternal tail-enders, the Yankees tonight crashed into an inelegant upset as the Athletics, with Phil Marchildon tossing a rather fancy four-hitter, captured the opener of a three-game series, 4 to 3, before a crowd of 11,869.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened its two-week season at the City Center last night, and covered itself with anything but glory. The evening had got along to 10:30 before it managed to shake off some of its spiritlessness and get down to business.

Clayton, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

The showing at Bendel's for the press yesterday morning was in the fine tradition of that Fiftyseventh Street specialty house. Compliments are in order to the two designers, Berthe Stern Simmons and Priscilla, who made them, and to Mr. Leon who directed the collection.

The stock market was pushed back yesterday to the lowest levels in almost nineteen months under a fresh avalanche of selling. McConaughy for Governor and Raymond E. Baldwin for United States Senator at a brief session this morning at the Bushnell Memorial Hall. The vote was unanimous.

MANILA, Sept. 10--A typhoon with wind of a velocity of a hundred miles an hour entered Luzon from the Pacific yesterday and headed straight toward Manila. DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP)--The runaway Boston Red Sox, needing only one victory over the Detroit Tigers to clinch the American League flag, were stalled again today as the Tigers handed them their fourth straight defeat, 9 to 1.

Rindge on Madison Green. His reviewing stand was a straight-back chair set on the Town Hall lawn, in dappled maple shade.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 --J.E. Ferguson's gray colt Airborne 60-to-1 winner of the Epsom Derby, established his place as one of Britain's all-time great horses today with an easy victory in the classic St. Leger over a mile and six furlongs. WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Col. John T. Whitaker, author and war correspondent for The Chicago Daily News and The Washington Star, who was expelled from Italy in February, 1941, by Mussolini, died here last night in Walter Reed Hospital. His age was 40.

Homemakers who have not been quite sure whether they dare tackle a wallpapering job themselves will have a chance to try their hand at it at a three-day wallpaper clinic that opened yesterday at Gimbels.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 12 --The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application filed by the Federal Light and Traction Company and four of its subsidiaries under which the subsidiaries would be merged ...

For the dual purpose of expanding the market for playwrights and providing television with preBroadway productions, a fulllength play bearing the odd title of "Mr. Mergenthwirker's Lobblies" will be televised Sept. 22 at 8:30 P.M. over WNBT as the first offering ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The White House today made public a plan that is expected to end the strike of two American Federation of Labor unions in the shipping industry, but settlement of the threatened strike by members of the Congress of Industrial, Organizations may be somewhat delayed.

Square dancers are invited to the Mall in Central Park tomorrow at 2 P.M. for the final Park Department dance program of the summer. Ed Durlacher calls the sets and the Top Hands provide gay music. Watching is almost as much fun as dancing! Sam Donahue and his orchestra will be on ...

Rationing of meat for restaurants was demanded yesterday by spokesmen for the city's principal consumer groups as housewife tempers flared over the relative abundance of roasts and chops in public eating places while most homes faced a week-end of little or no meat.

DETROIT, Sept. 12--The arrival today of Bucky Harris to join the Yankees, following Bill Dickey's announcement last night that he had notified Larry MacPhail, club president, he was not to be considered available as 1947 manager, had the New York entourage seething with excitement tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12--Dr. Wells P. Eagleton, noted specialist in brain, eye and ear surgery and dean of Newark physicians, died yesterday of a heart attack at Wentworth-by-the-Sea, a Portsmouth, N.H. hotel, where he had spent the summer. He was 81 years old. His home here was at 212 Elwood Avenue.

Joseph William Kennedy, truck driver and father of five, admitted yesterday he has worked harder than ever since he's been out on strike, tending his Chelsea backyard garden at 359 West Twentysecond Street.

When the war ended it was assumed that the nurses who had been discharged from the Army and Navy would return to the hospitals. Instead many of them have taken advantage of the GI Bill of Rights to train themselves for new vocations, or they have entered industry.

Not at all happy over the turn of events that pushed them into the National League cellar, the Giants yesterday launched a drive that Manager Mel Ott hopes will carry them back upstairs. Their resurgence took the form of a 4to-1 triumph over the Reds at the Polo Grounds.

The first step toward carrying out not merely the punitive but also the constructive provisions of the Potsdam agreement has now been taken with the creation of definite machinery for the economic unification of the American and British occupation zones in Germany.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12--A temporary injunction restraining New York City from dictating the amounts of milk that six major distributors may deliver in Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties and in eight near-by New Jersey counties was granted here today by Supreme Court Justice Charles W.U. Sneed.

LONDON, Sept. 12--The stock markets closed quietly and below the best levels reached in today's trading. After an early burst of activity reflecting overnight recovery on Wall Street interest slackened and profit-taking halted the rally.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12--Dr. Gilbert E. Seil, nationally known chemist and metallurgist, died here yesterday in Pennsylvania Hospital at the age of 57. He had undergone an operation two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- President Truman told reporters today that his plans to speak in the current Democratic campaign were still in the embryonic stage and that he planned no tour.

Secretary of Commerce Henry A. Wallace warned last night that the British imperialistic policy in the Near East combined with Russian retaliation would lead the United States straight to war unless we have a clearly-defined and realistic policy of our own.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 12 --At the suggestion of John. G. Winant, United States delegate, the Economic and Social Council will meet here tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. to tackle the refugee problem. But trouble was forecast in reaching agreement on the political definition of what is a "refugee."

Food and medicines moved more freely in the metropolitan area yesterday as non-striking truckmen resumed work under their contracts and two of the three striking locals of the teamsters' union agreed to expedite shipment of food and drugs. The volume of food moved was far from normal, however, and wash not large enough to end the chaotic conditions in its distribution.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--Outside interest in grains on the Board of Trade was light today. Prices broke early but rallied sharply in the late trading, largely on covering by shorts. Wheat lost 3 cents a bushel early on May which sold at a new seasonal low and 18 cents under the ceiling in effect on June 30 but recovered somewhat and the close was cent higher to 1 cents lower than yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--What few cattle were available today appeared to be by-passing Chicago for more profitable markets in the east--New York, Boston and Philadelphia -- while meat counters here remained bare.
The beat of boogie-woogie and the glide of the samba and rhumba may cease on Saturday night in New York's night club belt.

Thirty-five hundred barbers and 500 manicurists will strike next Monday morning and begin picketing 500 barber shops in Manhattan for higher wages, decreased hours and improvements in working conditions.

The expected thrilling battle for first place, which caused 32,043 ardent Flatbush fans to jam Ebbets Field yesterday, turned into an anticlimactic "no-contest" affair as the Cardinals flattened the Dodgers, 10--2, and increased their National League lead to two and one-half games.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 12--The 600 delegates attending the closing session of the sixtieth annual convention of the Printing Industry of America at the Hotel Traymore today unanimously adopted a resolution calling upon Congress to amend the National Labor Relations Act to provide for the settlement of disputes between employers and employes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--William L. Clayton, Acting Secretary of State, announced tonight that the United States would not stop shipments of United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration supplies to Yugoslavia in retaliation for the shooting down over that country of unarmed American transport planes last month.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP)--J. Cayce Morrison, assistant State education commissioner for research, said tonight that there was "scarcely a service rendered by libraries that is not affected by the current social trends."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP)--The pennant-bound Boston Red Sox failed again today to back into the American League championship as they bowed to Cleveland's Indians, 4 to 1, for their sixth straight setback, while the second-place Detroit Tigers were beating the Yankees.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--The more or less reviving Pirates took a 1-0 decision from the Braves in the first game of a double-header today for their fourth consecutive victory, but Boston rebounded and took the nightcap, 2--1.

Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that the City of New York had sold to a group of banks here $50,000,000 of tax anticipation notes maturing in equal amounts on Oct. 10 and on Oct. 17, at an interest rate of 0.625 per cent. Proceeds will be used for current expenses.

A systematic campaign has been waged by the private builders, materials dealers, producers, real estate interests, and even an agency of the Federal Government, the Civilian Production Administration, to undermine the Veterans Emergency Housing Program ...

DETROIT, Sept. 12--Acting with a perverseness difficult to explain, the Tigers continued to keep the clinching of the American League pennant in a state of suspended animation today as they vanquished the Yankees in the opener of a three-game series by a score of 6 to 4.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP)-- The Philadelphia Phillies took temporary possession of fifth place in the National League today through a 4-to-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the first game of a twin bill, then dropped back into sixth again as the Cubs put on a tenthinning rally to take the second contest, 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Average primary market prices declined 4.8 per cent during the week ended on Sept. 7, largely because of lower prices for livestock and meats upon reimposition of Office of Price Administration ceilings at the end of August.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Assurance that the question of returning the 131 wartime bases we developed in Panama would be worked out through friendly negotiations was given tonight through a joint statement issued by the United States and Panamanian Governments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12-- The latest star to go into picture production for himself is George Raft. With Sam Bischoff, a veteran Hollywood producer now at Columbia Studio, Raft has formed Star Films, Inc., which plans to begin actual shooting soon after Jan. 1.

Eddie Arcaro was riding with all his skill and Inroc was running with all his sped in the $5,500 added Class C Faireno Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, and the combination of their considerable talents resulted in a two-length victory for Jay Paley's colt in the role of $4.10-for-$2 favorite.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 12--Premier Ismail Sidky Pasha returned today from Rhodes, where he had flown for a consultation with King Farouk I, with a portfolio containing the names of a new three-party Cabinet and the virtual assurance that on the basis of reported new British concessions the AngloEgyptian treaty negotiations would be concluded this month.

PARIS, Sept. 12--Paris conference circles and the French public were startled today by a statement made in Washington by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery in which he said British and American military leaders were studying a plan to standardize their two armies.

NANKING, Sept. 12 (AP)--Confronted by the loss of military positions to Government troops, the Chinese Communists today proposed that the recently inactive Marshall military committee meet at once and work out a quick truce to end China's civil strife.
Management and community organizations working for community fund raising were told yesterday to "make room for newcomers" in the field of organized charity.

PARIS, Sept. 12--Guy Mollet, the new secretary of the Socialist party, wrote today to Jacques Duclos, secretary of the Communist party--whom he addressed as "Dear Comrade"--that the executive committee of the Socialists had decided that "the serious differences ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12-- Members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific voted unanimously at a meeting here tonight to end the seamen's strike on the West Coast at midnight and begin returning to their ships at 8 A.M. tomorrow.

Ruth McKenney, author of "My Sister Eileen," and her husband, Richard Bransten, who under the name of Bruce Minton was formerly Washington correspondent of The New Masses, have been expelled from the Communist party for conducting a factional struggle against the party line and its national leadership.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--Discovery of two new drugs which hold promise for the successful treatment of sleeping sickness was reported today at the meeting of the American Chemical Society here by Dr. Ernest A.H. Friedheim and Henry J. Vogel of the E.A.H. Friedheim Laboratory of New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12-- The National Pacing Derby attracted a crowd of 14,048 fans to the Roosevelt Raceway tonight. With eleven of the best harness horses of the United States and Canada entered, the event was the richest invitational race in the history of the sport.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 12--Winner of the jumping championship at Stony Brook last week-end, Raymond H. Lutz, 6-year-old bay gelding Easy Winner Jr. from Wilton, Conn., captured the $1,000 jumper stake on the first day of the forty-first annual Piping Rock Horse Show today. Jim Dawling rode him.

An end of the nation-wide maritime strike was in view early today as the Sailors Union of the Pacific, one of two striking American Federation of Labor seafaring affiliates, accepted a formula advanced by Dr. John R. Steelman for a settlement of its current wage increases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Eight cases of malpractice in the disposal of surplus radio, radar and other electronics equipment have been turned over to the Department of Justice for appropriate action, Robert M. Littlejohn, head of the War Assets Administration, advised a Congressional committee today.

A Secret Service agent, who posed as a West Coast racketeer and dope peddler, was credited yesterday by the Treasury Department with smashing a currency counterfeiting ring and "recovering the largest haul of bogus money in ten years."

Economic Stabilizer John R. Steelman has issued an amendment to the wage stabilization rulings which provides that if an industry agrees to pay a wage increase under conditions which do not require Wage Stabilization Board approval, then a Government agency which performs the same or a comparable service may pay the same rates without recourse to the WSB or any other stabilization agency.

THOSE who despair of contemporary writing--and they are lugubrious fixtures of every age --can always go back to the reassuringly certified writings of yesterday, finding there not only pleasure and ...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 12-- The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America took the lead today among the "big three" of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in demanding immediately an interim round of wage increases in all new contracts which would be subject to revision upward once a new national pattern has been established.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--A hearing to determine whether or not dairy products should be returned to price controls has been called by the Price Decontrol Board for Sept. 18.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept, 12--Terming the Wage Stabilization Board's attitude as "dictatorial," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today that the AFL would never accept the WSB decision and would stand by the striking seamen in the present nation-wide maritime strike.

Immediate decontrol by the Office of Price Administration of fabrics utilized in draperies and upholstered furniture was demanded yesterday by Richard Pohlers, vice president of Simtex Mills, in an address before the regular quarterly meeting of the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Demands by District 50, United Mine Workers, AFL, for time and a half for overtime on late trains was called unfair yesterday by a railroad representative, testifying before a three-man Presidential fact-finding board seeking to avert a strike on the Long Island Rail Road.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- A nation-wide drive to smash alleged black market dealings in textiles, including men's shirts, was disclosed today by the Justice Department.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 12 --Backed by support from the United States, Great Britain and China, American newspaper editors today urged an end to delay in adopting an official United Nations covenant establishing world freedom of information and warned that failure to act would weaken faith in the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12-- Proposed liberalization of the canon governing remarriage of divorced persons of the Protestant Episcopal Church, long a controversial issue, was debated for two hours this afternoon in the House of Bishops' session of the Fiftyfifth Triennial General Convention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--A recommendation that the Civilian Production Administration's lowcost clothing program covering cotton clothing should be continued through the fourth quarter of this year, was made today by that agency's group of special consultants on cotton, which met with board officials today.

Taking cognizance of numerous complaints by exporters who want to gain entry into the British market, the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce has broadened the "British token plan" to include non-branded merchandise, L.L. Horch, regional...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The bodies of the five American airmen shot down over Yugoslavia on Aug. 19 lay side by side tonight before the bare, non-denominational altar in a chapel under the great stone ampitheater in Arlington Cemetery.

PARIS, Sept. 12--Two commissions of the Conference of Paris-- those dealing with the political and territorial clauses for Finland and Rumania--finished their work today well in advance of the Oct. 5 deadline set for their reports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--More people voluntarily moved to America during the war than the Nazis forcibly moved into Germany and more United States citizens moved for personal reasons than were called into the armed services, the Census Bureau reported today.

For the fifth consecutive week, reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System here showed yesterday that their loans to commercial, agricultural and industrial borrowers had reached a record peak.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The Department of Agriculture stated today that it would cease to buy United States meat for cash-paying foreign Governments on Sept. 30, in line with a policy of returning food procurement for export to regular commercial channels as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Legislative representatives for the American Legion announced today that they were registering under the new lobby control act, but called it a weak and flexible statute that would deny to Congress and the public a true picture of financial operations by some pressure groups.

A decisive and encouraging trend toward more reasonable thinking was visible yesterday among the truckdriving unions, and after twelve days of increasing paralysis in the city Local 807 has at last agreed to start negotiating terms of settlement.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11 (Delayed)--Argentina has established "thought control." It has been announced that a bureau has been established within the Ministry of Commerce and Industry to deal with "malicious lies," to which ...
PARIS, Sept. 12--A salon redecorated in white and red and massed with red flowers was the background for a luncheon party at which Vera Borea presented her collection.
The Duncan-Paris Post of the American Legion, of which Marion Hargrove, author of "See Here, Private Hargrove," is commander and which includes many artists and writers in its membership, has ...

With trucks operating under union contracts moving without interference in this city and 10,000 idle drivers back at work in New Jersey, negotiations for a settlement of the paralyzing truck strike here got under way last night at City Hall for the first time since 15,000 general truck drivers quit work Sept. 1.
With beef, veal and pork supplies at a record low, we're back again to relying on poultry, fish and eggs for filling in the menu gap.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Delay in the conducting of an on-theground inquiry into the military government in the American zone in Germany, where conditions reportedly have been compared unfavorably with the German occupation of France during the war, caused today the first open conflict within the Special Senate War Investigating Committee in its five years of operations.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 12 Louis Hollander, State president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged tonight that Governor Dewey had "completely failed the people on the vital issues of racial discrimination, social security, labor legislation and education."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Truman said in his press conference today that he approved the speech delivered in New York tonight by Secretary of Commerce Henry A. Wallace and that he considered it to be in line with the policies of Secretary of State James F. Byrnes.

LONDON, Sept. 12--The Economist, a Liberal weekly, reviewing the American stock-market decline, said today that "America's real economic intentions are every bit as enigmatic as Russia's real political objectives" and that erecting ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--During the week ended Sept. 11, member bank reserve balances increased $97,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Considerable restraint was exhiited yesterday in the stock mark as general opinion in Wall Street turned cloudy over the immediate course of prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 7 were 794,483 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 113,957 cars, or 12.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 64,629 cars, or 8.9 per cent, ...

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 12-- The defending champion, the medalist, a former champion and a Glen Ridge star reached the semifinal round of the twenty-first annual women's New Jersey State championship at the Montclair Golf Club today.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 12--The agricultural committee of the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization urged today the immediate return of all nitrogen plants in Germany and Japan to maximum operation as an effective way of increasing world food production.

HALSTEAD, Kan., Sept. 12 (UP) --Dr. Arthur E. Hertzler, author of "The Horse and Buggy Doctor," died of uremic poisoning this afternoon in the hospital he founded here forty-four years ago. His age was 76.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended with July a rise in net profit of 135 per cent to $4,196,300, equal to $1.94 a share on 2,062,722 common shares, ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- The $8,800,000,000 International Monetary Fund opened tonight its world-wide battle against fluctuating currencies by calling upon its thirty-nine member governments to set par values for their currencies within thirty days.

In reappointing Dr. Jacob Greenberg to his third term as associate superintendent of the New York City schools, the Board of Education has maintained the high standards of the local educational system. Many serious problems face the schools in the trying post-war years ahead.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Following is the text of the statement issued by the Office of Economic Stabilization today in the seamen's wage case:

Several reasonable conclusions seem to emerge from preliminary study of the newly issued report to the Mayor by his transit advisory committee, the comments made later by Chairman Gross of the Board of Transportation and the pertinent circumstances involved in our narrowly averted subway strikes a few months ago and the recent paralysis of the city in the trucking tie-up.

The "strike" of 172 children in protest against their transfer from Public School 16, at Forty-first Avenue and 104th Street, Corona, Queens, continued yesterday as their parents still refused to allow them to attend classes in the three other Corona elementary schools to which they had been assigned.

"The Last Crooked Mile," a Republic melodrama featuring Don Barry and Ann Savage, which arrives at the Rialto, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Adele Mara, Tom Powers and Sheldon Leonard appear in supporting roles.

Elberon Hall, a nine-story apartment house at 385 Central Park Weat, adjoining the southwest corner of Ninety-ninth Street, has been sold by the Donald Holding Corporation to an investing client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys.

LONDON, Sept. 12--Great Britain will begin to repatriate her 394,000 German prisoners of war at an average rate of 15,000 a month by the end of this month, a statement from 10 Downing Street said tonight.

VIENNA, Sept. 12--Dr. Oscar Wilheim, Jewish administrator of Austria's largest single administrative block of Jewish-owned properties awaiting restitution, is reliably reported to have been sentenced to two years in Siberia by a Soviet military court.
LONDON, Sept. 12--Mounted police tonight broke up a huge crowd that had blocked traffic outside Abbey Lodge in a demonstration in support of squatters who had seized the building.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--A certain amount of division in the administration over acts and policies is inevitable for several reasons just now.

Opening its twenty-ninth annual fund drive, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that its goal has been set at $12,000,000. This is 33 1/3 per cent more than was sought last year.

John Kramer of Montebello Calif., newly crowned national amateur tennis champion, will play 26-year-old Torsten Johansson of Stockholm in the opening match of the Davis Cup interzone round with Sweden today in the Forest Hills Stadium. The series will be inaugurated at 2:30.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 12 Marvin (Bud) Ward's five-year reign as holdover national amateur golf champion came to an end today when he was eliminated in a third round upset by Charley Lind, 24-year-old Denver University senior, at Baltusrol.
Wilson W. Wyatt, National Housing Expediter, yesterday condemned what he characterized as "public complacency" over the black market in building materials endangering the veterans' housing program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 12 --Postponement of the United Nations General Assembly meeting at Flushing Meadows from Sept. 23 until Oct. 23 has been formally approved by a majority vote of member nations, it was announced here today by Trygve Lie, Secretary General.

Mayor O'Dwyer broke the ground yesterday for a new addition to the Decatur Junior High School, at Decatur Street and Lewis Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant Section of Brooklyn, in a ceremony opening the Board of Education's postwar school building program which is expected to include the erection of nearly 100 schools.

PARIS, Sept. 12--Soviet Vice Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky has revised and asked the deletion in Tass dispatches of his statement reflecting on Italian bravery that caused a protest by the Italian Ambassador and brought him a Rome lawyer's challenge to a duel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Gen. John J. Pershing, who will observe his eighty-sixth birthday tomorrow, declared today that "in this post-war period of international differences, it is incumbent upon our country to enforce our diplomacy with continued strength."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 12 --Despite apparently irreconcilable differences between the Soviet Union and Great Britain on the controversy over Greece, an effort to evolve some sort of compromise will be made when the United Nations Security Council meets here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- More and cheaper canned fruits are in prospect. The Department of Agriculture reported today that this year's pack is expected to set a new record, with slightly lower prices a possibility.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Truman indicated that he had no intention of requesting Congress for additional legislation to support his "hold-the-line" stabilization program and that he had ample powers to combat inflation, strikes and unwarranted wage increases.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--Retail prices for sugar will advance two cents a pound under terms of an order issued today by the Office of Price Administration.

Favorites had the Friday-the13th jinx on 'em at Aqueduct yesterday, and only those among the crowd of 22,117 who eliminated the "money horses" before making their wishes known at the mutuel windows had any fun during the cool and windy afternoon.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 13--In full control by the left-wing element, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, ended its eleventh international convention here today.

Increasing numbers of students are staying away from their classrooms in public schools in Corona, Queens, it was disclosed yesterday at the Board of Education after a two-hour meeting of school officials and a delegation representing
Mrs. Eula MeClary, former newspaper writer and one of the first woman publicists, died Wednesday at her home in Washington, D.C. Her age was 60.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (U.P)-- Juvenile crime is decreasing. And J. Edgar Hoover, FBI director, said tonight that it "reflects a trend away from the period of wartime abandon to more normal living conditions."

The five-story business building, on a plot 50 by 75 feet, at 993-95 Avenue of the Americas, southwest corner of Thirty-seventh Street, has been sold by Bernard London to a bank for its own occupancy. It was sold through Irving S. Wolper, broker, subject to a first mortgage of $205,000 for five years. The building contains
Camping on the sidewalk on Jamaica Avenue in the heart of Richmond Hill, Queens, gained an apartment for Joseph Ziaya, exArmy captain and Purple Heart holder, and his wife yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 13--Walkouts by Slav members and a British delegate from stormy debates in two commissions today marked the start of the Paris conference's discussion of its fundamental dispute--that over Trieste. To block a demand by Ambassador ...

Francis L. McElroy, Democratic State campaign manager, charged yesterday in an interview at Democratic headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel that Governor Dewey was using the war-created half-billiondollar State surplus as a political slush fund with extravagant promises to the people of the State as a bait for their votes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--Reconversion Director John R. Steelman told the Automobile manufacturers Association today that the automobile industry was in no danger of shutting down for want of lead for batteries and other purposes and said the present acute shortage of the metal would not be relieved by an increase in the ceiling price.

ALBANY, Sept. 13--Dr. Charles J. Blanford, administrator of the New York milk marketing area informed the State Temporary Commission on Agriculture that he would be unable to conduct the commission's investigation of the milk price spread.
The stock market managed yesterday to make some progress on the recovery side but the cautious tone of dealings prevailed with a further contraction in business.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP)--Mayor Erastus Corning of Albany renewed his campaign attack on Governor Dewey tonight, accusing Mr. Dewey of "bleeding" New York State taxpayers during the war to build up history's greatest "political slush fund."

At 5:27 yesterday afternoon 22.549 Flatbush fans heaved a tremendous sigh of relief when a lightning throir from Bruce Edwards to Eddie Stanky cut down Joffre Cross in his attempted steal of second base to end the second game of the all-important series With the Cardinals and give the Dodgers a 4-3 triumph.

The United States Davis Cup tennis team won the opening two singles matches from Sweden in the inter-zone round at Forest Hills yesterday and needs only to take one of the three remaining contests to qualify as the challenger of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--Price advances ranging from 26 up to 50 per cent were authorized by the Office of Price Administration today for several minor leathers domestically produced from imported raw stocks. The increases were allowed, OPA said, to compensate for sharp advances in foreign prices for raw skins.
Michael Mindlin, play producer and operator of motion-picture theatres, died yesterday in his home, 205 West Fifty-seventh Street. His age was 54.

A new State training program designed to qualify young men and women for employment in positions between the trade and the professional levels got under way yesterday when the city branch of the New York State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences named Otto Klitgord, technical consultant to the superintendents of the New York City Board of Education, as director.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 13 (AP)--The United States Army tonight clamped down on black marketing by American soldiers by substituting scrip for Allied-issued German marks as the legal currency in all military stores and other establishments in the United States occupation zone of Germany.

How to tell when children are ready for nursery school, reasons why some children do not like to go to nursery school, and ways of helping them to get along happily when parents have no choice in sending them are points discussed in the forthcoming journal of the Association for Childhood Education, 1201 Sixteenth Street Northwest, Washington 6, D.C.

The Navy began to evacuate its air base at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday and by tonight all Navy personnel except for a few small units will have cleared the field, leaving it ready for occupancy by commercial airlines through an agreement with Mayor O'Dwyer. However, city officials gave no indication of when they planned to take over the field.

In an effort to determine the most satisfactory ratio of professional and practical nurses on hospital staffs, the New York State Committee of the National Association for Practical Nurse Education will introduce a six-month hospital-duty program, it was announced yesterday by Miss Hilda Torrup, association president.
Just at the edge of high tide one finds pools of salt water that twice in each lunar day are renewed by offerings of the waves that come climbing up the rockweed-carpeted granite.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13-- Argentina has cut off all wheat shipments for Brazil which normally obtains her grain for bread from Argentina. Not an ounce of wheat has left Argentina since mid-July ...

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP)--Payment of $17,218,520 in accrued interest on four bond issues of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and its subsidiaries was approved today by Federal District Judge George H Moore, as he dismissed reorganization proceedings of the MissouriIllinois Railway Company.
In the tangled skeins of contemporary international relationships it is often difficult to see the ordered system of a better future.

Plans for a new $750,000 library as a memorial to Archbishop Michael A. Corrigan, founder of St. Joseph's Seminary at Dunwoodie, Yonkers, will be announced in a pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman to be read at all masses tomorrow in Catholic churches of the New York archdiocese.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Sept. 13 (U.P.)--An international commission to draft a plan for federating the five Central American republics was agreed upon by the Presidents of Guatemala and El Salvador in a meeting at Santa Ana, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13--Spruille Braden, Assistant Secretary of State, told the Executives Club at a noonday luncheon meeting today that he favored the financing of Latin-American industrial development with private investment capital rather than with Government funds.

PARIS, Sept. 13--The conference of Paris has arrived at its most crucial issue. The debate began this morning in the Territorial and Political Commission for Italy on the statute for the international territory of Trieste.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 13 --The system of simultaneous interpretation used at the Nuremberg trials had its first official run here today at a meeting of a committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, that on negotiations with non-government organizations.

Wallace C. Speers, chairman of the Laymen's Movement with headquarters at 347 Madison Avenue, received a letter yesterday from James F. OTTAWA, Sept. 17--Prime Minister W.L. Acting to unify the detective command in Brooklyn as he had previously done with the uniformed command, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander yesterday named Deputy Chief Inspector William T. Reynolds to head all Brooklyn and Richmond detectives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17--Justice Peyton Gordon, formerly of the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia, died here today at his home. He suffered a heart attack on Sunday. His age was 76.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Wilson W. Wyatt, Housing Expediter, made public today details of a premium payment plan for the merchant pig iron industry. The ninth in a series of such plans, its aim is to increase by one-third production of the metal.

Fall is infinitely better than spring, especially if grass is to be sown. This season favors root expansion and the storage of food. There is also less weed competition than in warm weather.

NOW is the time for all good amateur photographers to make plans for going back into "business." The proph ets say that the whole supply picture will be far better by early spring, and there are several facts and promises to support their predictions.

ROCK GARDENS in most places need overhauling in the fall, and September is a good time to begin. They may be badly run down because vegetables had first call, or they may have become slightly less than perfect through summer neglect. A well planned schedule and assiduous work should bring results in the first days of spring.

The wholesale markets here were quiet last week, with many concerns closed for two days because of the Jewish holidays, according to the market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Lehman.

Twenty-five managing editors and news editors of newspapers from coast to coast will meet at 9 A.M. today in the opening seminar of the recently established American Press Institute in the School of Journalism Building at Columbia University. TRENTON, Sept. 29--The new Jersey Legislature, in special session at noon tomorrow, will be asked by Gov. Walter E. Edge to carry forward a proposed veterans' emergency housing program from where the Federal Government, according to the Governor, virtually has halted.

ROME, Sept. 30--In a brief address to delegates of the National Association of Italian Christian Workers, Pope Pius XII today enunciated six points on which the Holy See's policy during the Second World War was founded.

KADIEVKA, Ukrainian S.S.R., Sept. 12 (Delayed)--The reconstruction of this mining town, one of the most important in the Don Basin, is being directed by a brisk, smiling woman of 30, Maria Nicolayova Pushkarvea.

Figures furnished by the Forest Service of the United States Department of Agriculture show that our timber resources are steadily declining. RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 29-- Robbers cut their way last night into the night depository vault of the Merchants Trust Company and made off with deposits estimated at between $29,000 and $50,000, most of it in cash.

Members of the Park Association of New York, accompanied by representatives of other civic groups, resumed yesterday their annual inspection of Bronx parks and recreational areas after an interruption since 1939. CHICAGO, Oct. 2--A bull market in grains developed today on the Board of Trade, paced by corn, which was bought by Eastern interests, cash firms and brokers who frequently act for exporters and the finish was at gains of 2 1/8 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York will open its 105th season tonight at Carnegie Hall. Real estsate bonds sold off in September for the third consecutive month and marked the largest recession since the break in July after a record four years of sustained bull market, Amott, Baker Co. reported yesterday.

ONE of the most remarkable books published last year was a fresh col lection of poems by Emily Dickinson: "Bolts of Melody." It was just a half century ago that the third volume of her lyrics appeared. Her work, the victim of various eclipses, is thus coming into clear view at last. The recent volume contains her own pithy comment on the "vital light" of poetry that survives the poet.

Sharp Dohme, Inc., have declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Nov. 1, marking the first time in several years that the company has voted a third disbursement on the common stock in a year.

Eighteen companies were suspended yesterday from dealing in, transferring or using sugar by Clifford R. Snider, chief hearing commissioner of the Office of Price Administration. The concerns were charged with having violated OPA sugar rationing regulations in connection with the disposal of 94,000 pounds of the commodity.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 5 (AP)--The United States Army reported today that the venereal disease rate among American troops in Germany declined during the first three weeks of September to the lowest point since last May. The decrease from August was 8 per cent.
A young Chinese woman was thrown by the horse she was riding in Central Park yesterday and a patrolman going to her aid was injured when his horse stumbled and fell.
